docs.lead_paragraph: In today's Patient Money column, Lesley Alderman writes about the various ways parents can find health coverage for their children, even if they think they can't afford it.
docs.abstract: Almost 10 percent of children, or seven million of them, still do not have insurance. One reason is that many parents don't know they are eligible for government-subsidized care.
docs.snippet: Almost 10 percent of children, or seven million of them, still do not have insurance. One reason is that many parents don't know they are eligible for government-subsidized care.

docs.lead_paragraph: Here's what's on my mind right now:

headline.main: Things I've Been Thinking About This Week

docs.abstract: I've done my share. How about the rest of you? Are you hiring?
docs.snippet: I've done my share. How about the rest of you? Are you hiring?

docs.lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.
docs.abstract: The biggest barrier to using pay-for-performance in health care is the difficulties of defining and measuring performance, an economist writes.
docs.snippet: The biggest barrier to using pay-for-performance in health care is the difficulties of defining and measuring performance, an economist writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the first decision in more than 15 cases against the new law, a judge in Detroit ruled in favor of the Obama administration.
